journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Double-Bundle Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction Using Bone–Patellar Tendon–Bone Allograft
title-group.subtitle: Technique and 2- to 5-Year Follow-up

article-meta.aff: *Institute of Sports Medicine of Peking University Third Hospital, Beijing, People’s Republic of China
Investigation performed at the Institute of Sports Medicine of Peking University Third Hospital, Beijing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: †Jia-Kuo Yu, MD, PhD, Institute of Sports Medicine of Peking University Third Hospital, No. 49 North Garden Road, Haidian District, Beijing, People’s Republic of China 100191 (e-mail: yujiakuo@126.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

abstract.p: Background: Nonanatomic transtibial single-bundle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (SB-ACLR) with a bone–patellar tendon–bone (BPTB) allograft has been used for a long time and has shown the same satisfactory clinical results as an autograft; however, it has not been reported if a double-bundle ACLR (DB-ACLR) could be performed with a BPTB allograft and achieve even better results.
Hypothesis: The DB-ACLR with a BPTB allograft is technically feasible and will be superior to the SB technique in restoring better anterior and rotating stability.
Study Design: Cohort study; Level of evidence, 2.

Methods: The study was performed with 56 patients, and 52 (25 in the DB group and 27 in the SB group) of them were followed up at 2 to 5 years. With an irradiated deep-frozen BPTB allograft, a standard single-incision arthroscopic technique was used, and the graft was fixed with bioabsorbable interference screws on both the femoral and tibial sides. Outcome assessment at final follow-up included International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC), Tegner, and Lysholm scores; side-to-side difference by conventional KT-2000 arthrometer; total anteroposterior (AP) laxity by the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer; pivot shift (0, +, ++); range of motion (ROM); and isokinetic muscle strength evaluation.

Results: Mean follow-up was 47.3 ± 11.5 and 58.2 ± 6.6 months for the DB group and SB group, respectively. A statistically significant difference in favor of the DB group was found with the total AP laxity at 30° (P < .05). The overall incidence of pivot shift in the DB group (4% ++) was significantly lower than that in the SB group (26%: 19% + and 7% ++; P = .029). No significant differences were found between the 2 groups in terms of IKDC score, Lysholm score, Tegner score, conventional KT-2000 arthrometer anterior laxity, ROM, and muscle strength.

Conclusion: A DB-ACLR with a BPTB allograft is feasible and achieved more satisfactory results than the transtibial SB technique in terms of total AP stability and rotational stability in spite of no significant differences among other clinical parameters.

body.p: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) serves as an important stabilizing function for the knee joint. The disability of the joint caused by rupture of the ACL leads to episodes of giving way, recurrent injury to the menisci, and degenerative changes.16 Anterior cruciate ligament reconstructions (ACLRs) are performed in an attempt to restore knee kinetics and stability. As a common graft, the bone–patellar tendon–bone (BPTB) autograft has performed well for ACLR14,32 but with some complications including anterior knee pain (25%-38%),29 patellar tendinitis, patellar tendon rupture (0.06%),25 patellar fracture (0.12%),25 patellofemoral arthrofibrosis (15%-41%),29 and quadriceps weakness. Consequently, it was estimated in 2007 that 20% to 30% of primary ACLRs were performed using allografts,12 and an earlier estimation was about 20% to 25%.6 Further, allograft tissue is often preferred because of the advantages in avoiding graft-tunnel mismatch in ACL revision surgery, decreasing surgical time, and solving the problem of autograft availability in multiligament injuries and concomitant reconstructions. Some reports have indicated no significant difference in terms of clinical results between the BPTB allograft and autograft for single-bundle ACLR (SB-ACLR).10,20,23,34,37

However, some shortcomings of the SB-ACLR with a BPTB autograft were gradually revealed. A normal International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score was shown in only 61% to 67%,8 and a rate of residual pivot shift of 0% to 30% had been reported in different studies about SB-ACLR with an autograft.29 On the whole, the conventional SB-ACLR provides the knee with sufficient anterior stability but insufficient rotational stability.45 The reason might be that the SB protocol cannot completely reconstruct the anatomy of the native ACL.18 The fibers of the ACL can be divided into 2 functional bundles: the anteromedial and posterolateral.33 Double-bundle ACLR (DB-ACLR) has been reported to be able to reconstruct ACL anatomy better and to restore normal knee anteroposterior (AP) stability and rotational stability more closely than the SB technique.47,48

Surgical DB procedures, which currently use hamstring autografts, have been described.48 However, some concerns exist regarding hamstring graft fixation and the ability to obtain adequate bundle sizes. Also, tunnel expansion has been significantly more common after ACLRs using hamstring tendons than in those using a BPTB autograft.27 The BPTB graft, which was considered the biological gold standard32 for primary and revision ACLR surgeries, might be a better option for DB-ACLR owing to bone-to-bone integration. Pujol et al35 reported the technique of DB-ACLR (2 femoral and 1 tibial tunnel) with a BPTB autograft. However the BPTB autograft with a 12-mm diameter might often not be enough for DB-ACLR and might cause too much donor-site morbidity. On the other hand, the superiorities of the BPTB allograft in DB-ACLR include bone-to-bone integration, enough graft size, and no donor-site morbidity. In spite of those superiorities, technical difficulties owing to the bone plugs of the BPTB allograft still exist for DB-ACLR. At the time of our study, there was still no report of the technique and the clinical follow-up for a primary 4-tunnel DB-ACLR using a BPTB allograft.

The purpose of the present study was to report a unique technique of DB-ACLR using a BPTB allograft and compare the clinical outcome of the new technique with that of the nonanatomic conventional transtibial SB-ACLR with a BPTB allograft. The hypothesis was that the DB-ACLR with a BPTB allograft is technically feasible and may be superior in restoring anterior and rotational stability of the knee joint. Meanwhile, the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer was used to confirm whether there were advantages of DB-ACLR in total AP stability.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: The study was approved by the ethics committee of the hospital. From July 2005 to June 2008, 3757 ACLRs were performed in our department. A total of 111 patients chose to use allografts, and the other patients chose autologous semitendinosus and gracilis tendons (STGs). The patients selected DB or SB reconstruction based on their understanding about the information from the surgeons. Following the criteria of a prospective randomized study, 56 patients undergoing ACLRs with BPTB allografts were included in our study and were divided into a DB group and a SB group, each with 28 patients. Twenty-five DB and 27 SB patients completed the final follow-up. Only patients between 16 and 50 years old who were undergoing primary operation were included, and younger patients had to have radiographic confirmation of a closed epiphysis. The exclusion criteria included age more than 50 years, narrow middle intercondylar width (<12 mm measured during operation with the knee flexed to 90°), revision reconstruction, multiligament injury, bilateral ACLRs, total meniscectomy or more than one-third partial meniscectomy, and severe cartilage injury. There were 7 concomitant partial meniscectomies and 5 menisci repairs in the DB group. In the SB group, the procedures included 2 menisci repairs and 7 partial meniscectomies. Preoperative parameters of both groups are shown in Table 1 with no significant difference (P > .05). At the early stage of the clinical trial, the surgical procedure was sometimes changed from DB-ACLR to SB-ACLR during the operation because of technical difficulties. This led to the longer follow-up time in the SB group.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean (range) unless otherwise indicated. IKDC, International Knee Documentation Committee.

sec.title: Preparation of Grafts
sec.p: All surgical procedures were performed by one surgeon. Cryopreserved BPTB allografts were obtained from a State Food and Drug Administration (SFDA)–certified tissue bank (Yunkang Hengye Biological Company Ltd, Beijing, China). Before the surgical procedure, the grafts were thawed at room temperature. For the DB group, the BPTB allograft was prepared with a bone plug diameter of 8 mm and patellar tendon width of 10 mm. The length of the patellar bone plugs that would be implanted into the tibial tunnel was 25 mm for both the anteromedial bundle (AMB) and posterolateral bundle (PLB) grafts. However, the length of the tibial bone plug for the femoral tunnel was 25 mm for the AMB graft and 18 mm for the PLB graft. For the SB group, the BPTB allografts were prepared with a tendon width of 10 mm and both patellar and tibial bone plugs of 10 mm (diameter) × 25 mm (length). Two 2-mm holes were drilled through each bone plug with No. 5 braided polyester Syneture TI-CRON (Covidien, Mansfield, Massachusetts) passed through the holes for BPTB allograft pull and implantation. Then, the end of the bone plugs was marked by methylthionine blue (Figure 1).

caption.p: Preparation of a double-bundle bone–patellar tendon–bone allograft. Two No. 5 nonabsorbable sutures were passed through the drilled holes of each bone plug. Methylthionine blue was used to mark the bone side at the end of the bone plugs (arrows).

sec.title: DB-ACLR Protocol
sec.p: The DB reconstruction protocol was previously reported.35,49 The anatomic nomenclature used here refers to the ESSKA Scientific Workshop on Reconstruction of the Cruciate Ligaments held at Imperial College, London, in September 1993.5 At the femoral side, the PLB tunnel was located and drilled first. With the knee flexed to 90°, the PLB tunnel was located freehand with a 2-mm metallic Kirschner wire from the accessory anterior medial portal (AAMP, 1.5 cm lower than the normal anterior medial portal) and then drilled with an 8-mm-diameter drilling bit with the knee flexed to 120°. The center of the PLB femoral tunnel was located at the middle of the line joining the superficial and the deep femoral cartilage edge (Figure 2). The distance between the center of the PLB tunnel and the inferior cartilage border was 5 mm.26 Then, the AMB femoral tunnel was located with a metallic Kirschner wire with the knee flexed to 90° and drilled with an 8-mm cannulated drill bit with the knee flexed to 110°. The AMB tunnel center was aimed with a 6-mm femoral guide (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy, Andover, Massachusetts) from the AAMP at 8 mm inferior to the 12-o’clock position on the posterior roof of the intercondylar notch and 6 mm superficially from the deep cartilage edge of the lateral intercondylar wall (Figure 2). The ACL footprint stumps, lateral intercondylar ridge, and lateral bifurcate ridge should be taken as references if they can be observed.15

caption.p: Femoral bone tunnel positioning of the anteromedial bundle (AMB) and posterolateral bundle (PLB). The center of the PLB femoral tunnel was located at the middle of the line joining the superficial and the deep femoral cartilage edge. The distance between the center of the PLB tunnel and the inferior cartilage border was 5 mm. The AMB tunnel center was located at 8 mm inferior to the 12-o’clock position on the posterior roof of the intercondylar notch and 6 mm superficially from the deep cartilage edge of the lateral intercondylar wall.

sec.p: At the tibial side, the tibial guide (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy) was used to drill the bone tunnels. The tibial tunnel of the PLB was located at the PLB footprint with the tibial guide setting at 50° and away from the tibial tubercle 40° medially (Figure 3A). The PLB tunnel position was just at the medial side of the posterior horn insertion of the lateral meniscus, that is, at the posteromedial side of the posterior end of the lateral intercondylar spine (Figure 4, red ring). Then, the PLB tibial tunnel was drilled with a 2-mm metallic Kirschner wire guiding pin and an 8-mm cannulated drill bit. For the AMB tibial tunnel, the tibial guide tip moved from the front margin of the drilled PLB tibial tunnel to a point 7 mm superficial (bone bridge of 3 mm plus AMB tunnel radius of 4 mm). The direction of movement depends on the positional relationship between the AMB and PLB footprints, taking the shape and orientation of the intercondylar notch as a reference at the same time. The tibial guide was adjusted to 65° and away from the tibial tubercle 20° medially (Figure 3B). Then, the AMB tunnel was also drilled with the same guiding pin and an 8-mm drilling bit. Thus, a bone bridge of 3 mm between the AMB and PLB was maintained.

caption.p: The tibial guide placement for double-bundle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction with arthroscopy, viewing from the middle patellar portal (MPP). (A) For the posterolateral bundle, the tibial guide was adjusted to 50° and away from the tibial tubercle (TT) 40° medially. (B) For the anteromedial bundle, the tibial guide was set at 65° and away from the TT 20° medially.

Tibial tunnel positioning of double-bundle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (DB-ACLR) and single-bundle ACLR (SB-ACLR). AMB, anteromedial bundle; PLB, posterolateral bundle; ALB, anterolateral bundle; PMB, posteromedial bundle; LM, lateral meniscus; MM, medial meniscus; green line, the extension of the free margin of the LM anterior horn; yellow ring, tibial tunnel position of the SB-ACLR; red ring, tibial tunnel position of the PLB for DB-ACLR; blue ring, tibial tunnel position of the AMB for DB-ACLR.

sec.p: With a traction suture in each side, the prepared allografts for the PLB and AMB were pulled into the respective bone tunnels. First, the BPTB allograft for the PLB was routed from the tibia to the femur. When the patellar tendon’s attachment on the tibial tubercle (marked with methylthionine blue) was pulled 1 to 2 mm into the PLB femoral tunnel, the cortical bone side, that is, the patellar tendon attaching side (unmarked), was adjusted to face the AMB femoral tunnel (Figure 5). Then, the bone plug in the femoral PLB tunnel was fixed with a bioabsorbable interference screw (ConMed Linvatec, Largo, Florida). Next, the BPTB allograft for the AMB was routed into the AMB tunnel the same way. The cortical bone side, that is, the patellar tendon attaching side of the bone plug in the femoral tunnel, was rotated to face the PLB femoral tunnel. In this way, the patellar tendons of the AMB and PLB allografts were kept in the position of “face to face” to decrease the space between them and facilitate their integration during graft remodeling (Figure 5B).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of double-bundle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction with bone–patellar tendon–bone (BPTB) allograft. (A) The allograft was fixed with absorbable interference screws in both the femoral and tibial tunnels. (B) In the femoral tunnel, the anteromedial bundle was rotated 90° to keep the tendon part of the 2 bundles “face to face.” “T” and “B” represent the tendon and bone part of the BPTB graft, respectively. IS, interference screw.

sec.p: For the tibial side, the directions of the bone plugs in the 2 tibial tunnels were not so important, and bioabsorbable interference screws were also used. Both of the grafts’ bone plugs were fixed with maximum manual pull along the graft’s longitudinal axis, with the tibial tubercle pushed posteriorly at the same time, first at 20° of flexion for PLB fixation and then at 80° of flexion for AMB fixation.

sec.title: SB-ACLR Protocol
sec.p: Arthroscopic SB-ACLR was conducted with the transtibial technique. The exact tibial tunnel placement (Figure 4, yellow ring) was at the intersection of the free margin extension of the lateral meniscus anterior horn (Figure 4, green line) and the lateral slope of the medial intercondylar spine. In this way, the tibial tunnel was placed at the second quarter from the anterior by Harner’s quadrant evaluation,19 combining Staubli and Rauschning’s43 AP placement of about 43%. The anterior edge of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) fibers was also taken as reference concurrently to avoid individual variability. A 2-mm metallic Kirschner wire was drilled to the yellow ring center with the help of the tibial guide set at 50° and away from the tibial tubercle 20° medially.49

Through the tibial tunnel, the femoral tunnel for the SB-ACLR was located at the most proximal high deep point of the lateral intercondylar cartilage edge, a little bit inferior to the over-the-top site (Figure 6).28 When the transtibial technique could not place the femoral tunnel at an ideal position (3 cases), the tunnel was located with a 6-mm femoral guide through the AAMP.

caption.p: The femoral tunnel positioning (red ring) for single-bundle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction through the accessory anterior medial portal. A 6-mm femoral guide was placed at the position of the high deep point (purple) of the lateral intercondylar cartilage edge, a little bit inferior to the over-the-top site (green).

sec.p: The graft pulling and fixation were the same as DB-ACLR, but the patellar tendon side was turned toward the deep wall (posterior wall) of the femoral tunnel. The knee was maintained in extension when the tibial graft fixation was performed.

sec.title: Rehabilitation
sec.p: All the patients’ rehabilitation followed a standardized procedure. On the first day, quadriceps sets, straight-leg raises, and prone hangs were initiated. All of the patients were allowed to walk with crutches and braces but with no weightbearing. Range of motion was increased from 0° to 90° on postoperative day 3 to 7 and to 115° at the fourth week. Partial weightbearing with the use of a crutch and closed kinetic chain exercises were performed at the sixth week. Full flexion and weightbearing were mostly achieved at the eighth week. Patients progressed to running without braces at 4 to 6 months. Full sport activities were allowed after 6 months if the patient could fulfill the following requirements:

list-item.p: The isokinetic muscle strength of the injured knee was over 85% of the uninjured knee.
Hamstring/quadriceps (H/Q) ratio was at 80% or above.
Knee sensitivity, control, and coordination were adequate after training.

sec.p: For professional athletes, in addition to the 3 conditions, 1 to 2 months of basic fitness and transaction training was needed before returning to the field.

sec.title: Evaluation
sec.p: The follow-up evaluation was single blinded and performed by one surgeon who had not operated on any of the patients in the study at final follow-up. Subjective parameters included preoperative and postoperative subjective IKDC scores, Lysholm scores, and Tegner scores. Objective evaluations included range of motion, Lachman test, pivot-shift test, and muscle strength examination.

sec.title: KT-2000 Arthrometer
sec.p: The side-to-side difference was measured at final follow-up by KT-2000 arthrometer (MEDmetric, San Diego, California) at 15 lb, 20 lb, and 30 lb in 30° and 90° of flexion. Both the conventional anterior laxity (by routine KT-2000 arthrometer measurement) and the total AP laxity (by back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer measurement) of the knee joint were measured. The technique of the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer is as follows: at 30° or 90° of flexion, the patient relaxed himself or herself; next, the examiner pushed back the handle of the KT-2000 arthrometer with 20-lb force and set the zero point of the arthrometer while the tibia was kept in a back position. Then, the examiner applied an anterior force of 15 lb, 20 lb, and 30 lb, respectively, and recorded the results as the total AP laxity of the knee joint.

sec.title: Muscle Strength Examination
sec.p: At final follow-up, 22 patients of the DB group and 24 patients of the SB group underwent muscle strength evaluation with Biodex dynamometer (Biodex, Shirley, New York) according to the manufacturer’s guidelines. Strength testing was performed for knee flexion and knee extension at 60 and 120 deg/s. The mean peak torque of 5 maximal repetitions for each velocity was assessed to analyze the quadriceps and hamstring isokinetic strength, and the results of the operated leg were expressed as a percentage of that of the nonoperated side.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using the SPSS 10.0 software package (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois). The Mann-Whitney U nonparametric 2-tailed test and the χ2 test were used to compare each parameter between the DB and SB groups. The level of significance was set at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: No clinically observed immune rejection symptoms consistent with allografts were found. Table 2 provides the subjective comparison data at final follow-up. No significant difference was found in terms of IKDC, Lysholm, or Tegner score (P > .05). No positive Lachman test result was found for all the patients of the DB or SB group. According to the objective evaluations of Table 3, the overall incidence of pivot shift in the DB group was significantly lower than that of the SB group (P = .029). However, only 1 (4%) and 2 (7%) patients of the DB group and SB group, respectively, had a ++ positive pivot shift detected. Twenty-four patients in each group had a grade 0 pivot shift.

There was no statistical difference in the conventional KT-2000 arthrometer anterior laxity between the 2 groups (P > .05). On the other hand, the total AP laxity by the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer showed less translation in the DB group, especially at 30° (P < .05). Only 2 patients in the DB group and 1 patient in the SB group had a flexion restriction of more than 5°. One patient in each group had extension restriction of more than 5°. There was no significant difference between the 2 groups in either flexion or extension restriction (P > .05) (Table 3). As shown in Table 4, there was no significant difference in the muscle postoperative torque values between the 2 groups.

caption.p: Objective Evaluation of Both Groups at Follow-upa

tr.td: Back-pushing KT-2000 total anteroposterior laxity, mm

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean (range) unless otherwise indicated.

caption.p: Isokinetic Muscle Strength Evaluation of Both Groups at Follow-upa

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study reported the technique of 4-tunnel DB-ACLR using 2 BPTB allografts and compared the 2- to 5-year clinical results with those of SB-ACLR. The results demonstrated that this DB technique was a reproducible procedure that might be superior to the SB reconstruction, as judged by the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer results and pivot-shift test findings.

A significant difference was found between the result of the total AP laxity measured by the side-to-side difference on the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer and the conventional KT-2000 arthrometer results, which is a common index to evaluate anterior stability before and after ACLR. The DB group showed less total AP laxity at both 30° and 90° of flexion when compared with the SB group.

Among 8 published level of evidence I studies comparing anterior stability measured by conventional KT-2000 arthrometer between the SB-ACLR and DB-ACLR,‡ 3 of them showed DB had better anterior stability than SB, but 5 of them did not find a significant difference. Many variations among different studies could lead to no significantly different anterior stabilities of most of the evidence of level I studies. However, we believe the key point might be the conventional KT-2000 arthrometer method itself. Our study showed that the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer method might be able to reveal the superiority of DB-ACLR in restoring the total AP stability. According to some reports, total translation obviated the need to identify the neutral resting position of the knee and eliminated a potential source of error.13,17,36 In the present study, a posterior shear load was utilized to reduce variability; then, total anterior laxity was measured based on a zero point with back-loaded reference. For this reason, we suggest the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer should be used in DB-ACLR studies instead of the conventional KT-2000 arthrometer method to allow for total AP stability evaluation.

After DB-ACLR, the added PLB stays between the AMB and PCL and increases the tension of the PCL when the knee is flexed and extended. Thus, DB-ACLR is likely to allow less tibial excursion with back-pushing than SB-ACLR. This might be the reason for the difference between the 2 groups in terms of the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer. Furthermore, our recent unpublished research showed that the PCL index was near normal in the DB-ACLR group, but the PCL index in the SB-ACLR group was far less than the control intact knee group. This result could be another piece of evidence to explain the advantage of the back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer in evaluating the total AP laxity after DB-ACLR.

In addition, it should be noted that the significant difference of total AP laxity happened in 30° of flexion. According to some anatomic studies, the PLB is reported to be tighter in extension40 and the AMB of the ACL normally tighter in flexion. Gabriel et al18 also concluded that the PLB was particularly important under combined loads when the knee was near full extension but was relaxed at 90° of flexion. Therefore, the graft tension was increased at 30° by adding the PLB in the present study, and it might be the reason for the significant difference at 30° of flexion rather than at 90°.

Control of the internal rotation of the tibia was a focus of discussion on DB-ACLR. The pivot-shift test has been one of the most important methods to evaluate the rotation of the postoperative knee joint. According to other studies, the result of the pivot shift indeed varied greatly. A positive pivot-shift rate for SB autografts was reported as 0% to 30% for different studies.29 Biau et al9 reviewed 18 randomized controlled trials of SB-ACLR and indicated that the overall positive pivot-shift rate was 19% for the SB BPTB autograft. The overall result of the hamstring autograft reached 24%. Other studies confirmed that the positive pivot-shift rate of the BPTB allograft was even higher than that of the BPTB autograft, and the relative risk (allograft/autograft) was about 1.2 to 1.23.24,38 In the present study, a significant decrease of overall pivot shift was shown for the DB group (4%) compared with the SB group (26%). This result implied that the DB-ACLR knee using a BPTB allograft might achieve better rotational stability than the SB group, and the result was similar to other published evidence of level I studies of DB-ACLR.21,22,31,42,46 The reason might also be because of the adding of the PLB, which was shown to be a stabilizer against internal rotatory loads by Gabriel et al.18 The biomechanical study also had shown that the PLB resists anterior translation and internal rotation of the tibia on the femur in relative knee extension, and the AMB offered more restraint to anterior tibial translation in relative knee flexion.18 These bundles have different tension levels as the knee flexion angle changes, and the PLB was particularly important for providing transverse plane rotating knee stability as the knee nears full extension.40 Yagi et al47 also reported that anatomic DB reconstruction effectively controlled the internal rotation of the tibia more than SB reconstruction.

However, the difference in terms of the pivot shift ++ (4% vs 7%) was not so obvious. Meanwhile, it is in fact difficult to compare the results from different studies because the pivot-shift test result is subjective and observer dependent. So the significant difference between the 2 groups in our study could not absolutely establish the superiority of the DB reconstruction in rotational stability. Instruments and methods for quantitatively evaluating the rotational stability are being studied, and more objective results might be obtained in the future.

In terms of operative technique, DB reconstruction is generally considered more difficult than SB reconstruction. Especially for the present technique using a BPTB allograft, difficulties existed during the passage and fixation of bone plugs. For DB reconstruction, the tibial tunnel was not in a direct line with the femoral tunnel as it is for SB reconstruction using the transtibial technique. Given our technique reported above, the passage of the PLB with bone plugs in both sides was one of the largest challenges.39 Too long of a bone plug (>18 mm) might make it impossible to pull the bone plug from the tibial tunnel into the femoral tunnel, especially for the PLB graft implantation. After encountering some troubles for earlier cases, we defined the length of the tibial tubercle bone plug that would pass through the tibial tunnel and the joint cavity to the femoral tunnel as 18 mm. Afterward, no trouble of the bone plug passing happened again.

Several kinds of allografts have been used for DB-ACLR. Zelle et al50 presented an arthroscopic technique of anatomic DB-ACLR using tibialis anterior tendon allografts. Royalty et al39 reported the anatomic DB-ACLR surgery using fresh-frozen allograft tissue. However, no long-term clinical results had been reported until now. To our knowledge, this is the first study to use a BPTB allograft for anatomic primary DB-ACLR. The presented technique was unique in that it combined the advantages of the BPTB allograft with the advantages of anatomic reconstruction of the AMB and PLB of the ACL. Several superiorities were shown in terms of the technique and the graft choice. First, compared with SB reconstruction, a better anterior and rotational stability was observed after the DB reconstructive technique. Second, the BPTB allograft offered the advantage of 2 bone plugs’ bone-to-bone healing with their bone tunnels.32 So a better joint stability might be expected because this type of healing is considered to be stronger than that of the anterior tibialis tendon allograft, which has been a common graft for the current DB-ACLR.32 Meanwhile, compared with BPTB and hamstring autografts, a larger size of the ligament was supplied to meet the need for DB reconstruction. Besides, donor-site morbidity from graft harvest was nonexistent with BPTB allografts. The BPTB autograft with a 12-mm diameter reported by Pujol et al35 might often not be enough for DB reconstruction and might cause too much donor-site morbidity. However, the disadvantages of allograft tissue included the relative high cost, limited availability, risk of disease transmission, slowed graft incorporation, tissue rejection possibility, and alteration of the graft’s structural properties by sterilization and storage procedures.11,30,41 These should be presented frankly to the patients before they make the decision on graft choice.

There were still several limitations for our study. Although no significant differences were found in preoperative parameters, the study was not absolutely randomized because of clinical and individual factors that sometimes were very difficult to control. The patients selected DB or SB reconstruction based on their understanding about the information from the surgeons. Further, the number of patients and follow-up time were narrow, and a study including more cases and longer follow-up is necessary in the future. In addition, most of the SB reconstructions in our study used the transtibial technique rather than the anteromedial portal technique, which was reported to be able to more anatomically locate the femoral tunnel and improve restoration of anatomy and stability with ACLR.3,4,7 Thus, the result of the present study only indicated the superiority of the new technique to the conventional transtibial technique used in our hospital. A comparison between anatomic DB reconstruction and anatomic SB reconstruction with BPTB allografts is necessary in the future. Meanwhile, most of the patients in our study did not participate in strenuous activities after operation, and this might be the reason why no significant difference was found in terms of the subjective scores in spite of the difference in pivot shift. Follow-up would be necessary for postoperative athletes in further research.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: According to our 2- to 5-year follow-up, DB-ACLR with a BPTB allograft was technically feasible and showed more satisfactory total AP stability and rotational stability in spite of no significant difference in terms of subjective evaluations. Following an accurate operative technique and precise tunnel positioning, the DB BPTB allograft can be a reasonable alternative for routine primary ACLR. The back-pushing KT-2000 arthrometer might be used to reveal the advantage of DB-ACLR in restoring the total AP stability compared with the conventional KT-2000 arthrometer.

fn.p: One or more of the authors has declared the following potential conflict of interest or source of funding: This study was supported by the foundation “Second Period of 985 Projects” of Peking University Health Science Center.
